mods:mods.mods:abstract: Report against Congress ratifying convention concerning establishment of French and American consuls in both countries. Differences between initial scheme and convention outlined. If three purposes of the convention are: providing against infractions of French and American trade law, preventing migration between the countries and establishing officers whose purpose is promotion of commercial and political views, questions whether these things can promote American interests in France. Believes convention not reciprocal in putting consuls in French territories other than France and in matters of religious worship. Strongly against conventions in terms of language, as matter of precedent. Also unclear if powers refer to Congress or to individual states. Fears that granting of full immunity to consuls and all the people attached to the consulate and the maintenance of separate jurisdictions and legal conventions for French merchants and other citizens would separate French and American inhabitants in the United States. Implications of that immunity in arresting sailors, deserters, other ship passengers and cargo without recourse to American courts. As Congress has moved towards ratification, believes objections should be sent to American minister at Versailles with preference for scheme over convention plus addition of article limiting convention to 8-10 years.
